comments.body: how does subset make sense here? does it make sense to hide *some* columns?

The idea is that you may have columns that are needed for formatting -- determining the color of a row, for example -- but you may not want to display them.  For example, lets say you had a dataframe with columns City and AvgTemp.  Avg Temp was used by Styler to color each row.  But in the final rendering, you only want to display city (colored appropriately).  AFAIK there is no way to do that right now, but with this change you could do df.style.hide_columns(['AvgTemp']).  You only want to hide AvgTemp.
this is a bit unusual for pandas, but I think it's fine here. It's kind of like `drop`, except it's hiding instead of dropping.
maybe we should support ``df.style[list_of_selected_columns]`` for showing *some* columns. (separate discussion)

. e.g.

```
In [5]:         df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [0, 0], 'B': [1, 1]})
   ...:         f = lambda x: ['val: {max}'.format(max=x.max()) for v in x]
   ...: 

In [6]: df
Out[6]: 
   A  B
0  0  1
1  0  1

In [7]: df.apply(f, axis=1)
Out[7]: 
0    [val: 1, val: 1]
1    [val: 1, val: 1]
dtype: object

In [8]: df.apply(f, axis=1, result_type='infer')
Out[8]: 
        A       B
0  val: 1  val: 1
1  val: 1  val: 1

```

I am not entirely sure why you need this this way.

The above snippet is no longer correct (I mean: in the meantime we have chosen to not preserve the original columns names when a list is returned, so this will have column names [0, 1]). 

This has no impact on the style code?

comments.body:
Hmmm, I'm not sure about the option affecting `Styler`. Does anyone else (@jorisvandenbossche, @chris-b1) have thoughts?

Adding classes to the `Styler` is pretty easy, and you're always able to add them since you're generating the Styler. With `DataFrame._repr_html`, you don't have that option.

It's true this issue is solved by `df.style.set_table_attributes('class="tex2jax_ignore"')`. One could argue that this PR is unnecessary because the solution is already possible in pandas.

But this solution requires knowledge of how MathJax works â€“ something that I've learnt whilst making this PR. The new option `display.html.use_mathjax` is there to make it easier for users to find the solution.

To be clear, the changes to frames repr html are great.

I just worry about injecting â€œnoiseâ€ into Stylerâ€™s generated HTML from a config option, when itâ€™s relatively easy to do that yourself.

That said, an extra class isnâ€™t the worst thing in the world, and itâ€™s simple to toggle on and off. Your current PR is probably fine.
Yeah, I could see the argument for not doing it in `Styler` but I agree the PR is fine, especially where it is off by default, and is sort of an obscure thing to look up.

comments.body: I think this should be the summary more than a Notes section.

I'm inclined to leave this as "notes", for consistency with [pandas.DataFrame.pipe](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.pipe.html).  

Another reason to separate this from the function specification is that this section alludes to specific use cases for `pipe`, and conventions for the user-defined functions.  But I wouldn't want users to get the impression that they must use `pipe` like this -- there may be several other useful applications for the method that creative users will devise.

We'll chage `DataFrame.pipe` then (you can open yourself another PR for it). We should show this in the examples (no code blocks should be in any other section). And the code needs to show real-world examples, and needs to be runnable.

This was added at the request of @gfyoung [earlier in the review process](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23384#discussion_r228727737), who asked:

> Also, for what purpose?
> 
> (yes, as reviewers, we can see what the rationale was from your PR, so just put that rationale into the docstring)

@TomAugspurger [suggested making this a code block](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23384#issuecomment-435075033).

I think removing the code block may increase compliance with some developer rules for docstrings, but would make "rationale" part of the docstring less clear to end users.

@gfyoung, do you think the text-only rationale, without the code examples, is sufficient?
I like the code block here.

Not a big deal, but I don't think the code block will be run in the doctests, or validated for pep8 in the docstring validation. That's why I would prefer to have the code in the example, and not in code blocks (besides a personal preference on keeping all the code together).
This code block is more for showing why `pipe` is still useful despite being functionally equivalent to nested function calls. It's not intended as an actual example.

comments.body: Not exactly true, what happens with the `Styler` instance where this is being called? Don't we modify its result?

I'm not sure I understand your second question.

The user-supplied function `func` may or may not modify the styler; it may or may not have side-effects; and it may return the styler, some other result, or None.

Consider the `pandas.Series` case.  A user could write any of the following:

```
>>> s = pandas.Series(...)
>>> s.dropna().shift().pipe(normalize)        # Returns Series
>>> s.dropna().shift().pipe(trimmed_mean)     # Returns scalar
>>> s.dropna().shift().pipe(insert_initial_value)  # Unconventional, not "pand-onic"
>>> s.dropna().shift().pipe(save_to_disk)     # Returns string filename
```

comments.body: Can you just break this into separate for loops / functions? It's a little hard to grok what is going on here with the deeply nested comprehensions

The objective is for `Styler.table_styles` to be extended by `_Tooltip.table_styles`.
But each data cell (if has tooltip) needs two table styles, so the method `_pseudo_css` generates the list of 2 items for each data cell.
The nesting is only needed to flatten the list to allow the above objective in the right format: `[[a1,b1],[a2,b2]] -> [a1, b1, a2, b2]`.

Happy to take suggestions on structure, but previous versions have had requests for list comprehensions as opposed to separate loops.

why do we not just call `.clear()` first?

the `_compute` method deals only with the `_todo` list which is the composition of users `apply` and `applymap` methods. It populates the `ctx` object which is later used by `_translate` to render the HTML.

the `clear` method removes the `_todo` list as well as other objects such as `Tooltips`, the `ctx` object and the `cell_context` object from the `Styler`. You don't want to remove all these at this stage. I think you just want to empty the `_todo` list after its been 'done'.

comments.body: how / does this interact with the other parameters?

previously the data itself acted as the gradient map, so if axis=0,1 then each col or row was the map, and for axis=None the whole subset dataframe was the map. Now, you can explicitly overwrite that map with gmap, so this has the same interaction with smin, smax, vmin, vmax, which would normally apply to the data when the data as the map, but if gmap is supplied apply to that map instead.

```python
class Bar:
    pass

class Foo:
    def __init__(self):
        self.bar = [Bar()]

foo = Foo()
foo_a = foo
foo_c = copy.copy(foo)
foo_dc = copy.deepcopy(foo)

print(id(foo))
print(id(foo_a))
print(id(foo_c))
print(id(foo_dc))
print()
print(id(foo.bar))
print(id(foo_a.bar))
print(id(foo_c.bar))
print(id(foo_dc.bar))
print()
print(id(foo.bar[0]))
print(id(foo_a.bar[0]))
print(id(foo_c.bar[0]))
print(id(foo_dc.bar[0]))
```

comments.body: is there a reason we actually care about deepcopy, IOW why are we not just always a shallow copy? is this actually used somewhere?

Personally, I have never had use to copy a `Styler`. But I can see a use case where, in a notebook or report, you might have a dataframe that has some preliminary, shared styling and then some divergence where you highlight different properties as part of a narrative. 

I think, off the top of my head, in this scenario you would need a deepcopy to prevent any updates from intermingling with each other, since much of the core styling I think comes from the attributes where the shallow copy will have only single shared pointed reference.

comments.body: Can you validate position_float - only three values right?
yes I believe there are only three values. will take a look
Does it seem reasonable to validate position? I think the answer may be "no".
Not really, there are `h,t,b,p,!,H` but you can combine multiple and it is recommended to have a backup, e.g. 'h!'

What about:

```
valid_positions = {'h', 't', 'b', 'p', '!', 'H'}
invalid_positions = set(position).difference(valid_positions)
if len(invalid_positions) > 0:
    raise ValueError(f'Valid positions are {valid_positions}, got {invalid_positions}')
```

I too think this should *not* be validated.
LaTeX packages can define their own position specifiers and it is the responsibility of the LaTeX compiler to interpret these values.

i lean away from validation as it goes against duck typing, and it is difficult to ensure validation is consistent across pandas (or even in local functions). As moi90 mentions maybe the user has some reason for a non-standard value.

> LaTeX packages can define their own position specifiers

Thanks @moi90, this is a compelling reason to not validate.

comments.body: Is it possible to remove the necessity of : after bfseries
No, not unless we change how to parse CSS - a ':' is always present, and raises currently if missing.
A colon plus empty value plays more nicely with the additional wrapping options below, I think.

Right - I was thinking of parsing before we get to that step, something like:

```
props = 'cellcolor:{red}; bfseries;'
props = ';'.join([e + ':' if ':' not in e else e for e in props.split(';')])
props = props[:-1] if props[-1] == ':' else props
```
But perhaps there are various edge cases that make this hard.
@rhshadrach This looks like syntactic sugar to me. I would leave it out here and put it in a follow-up pull request once the overall mechanism is settled.
yes this change has other implications so I would also suggest making a follow on discussion.

@moi90 - I would not describe this as syntactic sugar, but rather as correcting a defect. That said, it doesn't seem significant to me, and I agree with your approach, but would like others thoughts here.

cc @jreback, @simonjayhawkins

For context: the current Styler has a method `maybe_convert_css_to_tuples` which is based on the `att: val; att2: val2;` format. It currently raises an error to user if format structure is not correct. If we deviate from this for LaTeX parsing, it would probably require changing the behaviour of that method, and would represent a departure from the make _'LaTeX Styler fit the normal CSS structure'_ and, in that case, it may well be worth  asking further questions about the best way to approach this, but my preference is to keep as is.

> If we deviate from this for LaTeX parsing, it would probably require changing the behaviour of that method

I don't understand why we can't introduce a compatibility layer instead as I've suggested above. If you've said why that is not a viable route, I seem to have missed it.

because 'props' is an argument to every built-in styling method (in this case `highlight_max`), which are all ignorant of whether you are styling CSS or LaTeX. So, if you add that compatibility layer to each one of these methods, i.e. **before** 'props' are all passed to `maybe_convert_css_to_tuple` you may as well add this compatability adjustment to `maybe_convert_css_to_tuples`, which will change the operation of that method but the code will, at least, have the same effect, not be duplicated, and not pollute all the built-in methods.

For transparency, I think `maybe_convert_css_to_tuples` happens late enough in the render process that a `latex` flag could differentiate between different rendering cases, and therefore introduce your code, without impacting CSS warnings.

I just preferred minimising additional complexity and relying on the user to fit the documented structure.
Ah, I didn't realize there wasn't a better place to intercept. Agreed, and thanks for the response!

do we need an option for this? why wouldn't we always do this?

We wouldn't want to convert if different settings for html and latex are wanted or if more control over the latex formatting is needed. But in that case, a new styler instance could easily be used, right?
right this is by-definition on `.to_latex` so i think its clear.

Styler now allows styling to be coded in LaTeX **or** HTML-CSS format. In each separate case, which are completely flexible in each format, you don't want to convert.
But, if you have created an HTML-CSS Styler and it contains the limited attr-values that can now be converted to LaTeX then you should use the convert option. Shouldn't be set to default though.
